text: [Grey] When an infection destroys a cell,
the surrounding cells signal each other to wall it off.
Help. I just had a Nissen fundoplication and I can't swallow.
- What's happening to me? - Are you you,
or are you still a 50-year-old man with achalasia?
- It doesn't say. - [sighs]
[Grey] They isolate the infected cell to prevent it from spreading
and harming other parts of your body.
[Helm] You think they'll ever talk to each other again?
[Yasuda] Don't know, don't care.
As long as they finish their procedure logs.
Besides, I'm too busy rushing you back to the OR
to loosen the wrap of your stomach.
Correct. You get a fry.
[Meredith] The isolation is temporary, but important.
I prefer the study technique you used the other night.
I'm not taking my clothes off here.
[Meredith] It gives your body time to trigger your immune system
and stop the infection from spreading.
Did you pick up those yogurt things that Leo loves this morning?
Sorry. An MVC came in.
Hey, does Pru go through those phases where she'll only eat two things?
We're at yogurt and graham crackers.
We are at "I'm going to shove food under my plate and pretend that I ate it."
-[chuckles] Any plans tonight, Bailey? - I have plans.
I have plans to take a bath,
and not think about interns for seven hours.
And then I'm also going to... the pit.
I'm going to the pit. Multiple traumas?
Yeah, me too. I'll page the interns.
All right, I'll pick up the yogurt. Good luck.
[Meredith] Until isolation is no longer needed.
Ready for tonight?
"I'm gonna make you an offer you can't refuse."
- What is that? - The Godfather.
- Oh. - It's movie night.
[grunts] We're on call. We should sleep when we can.
Every time I pick the movie, you're too tired to watch.
Not true!
I sat through that whole baseball movie.
- I should get extra points for that. - That was five weeks ago.
- [chuckling] No, it was not. - Yeah!
It was three Screams,
one Jason Bourne and Pride of the Yankees ago.
Five weeks.
Then I'm late.
For what?
My period.
[phones buzz, chime]
- It's the ER. - Should we ignore it?
- So is this. - [scoffs]
[Shepherd] I never thought I'd mean this literally,
but I'm reading about a bunch of random people's crap.
Are all of these adult children of people with Alzheimer's?
Well, we need to confirm certain bacteria in the gut.
Our hypothesis will be even more solid.
I'm going to need hard data if I'm ever going to approach Catherine again.
How can you eat while we're analyzing these results?
Becoming my mother terrifies me that much.
- [chuckles] - [phone chimes]
[Meredith] Zola. "Can Ellis have ice cream?"
No, she can't have ice cream. It's so late.
Parenting by text. I'm impressed.
Well, it only works because Zola's honest and mature.
That's the part that's impressive.
[phone chimes]
Nick is supposed to read Ellis a story. Well, ask Nick.
Do you think fried rice is an anti-inflammatory?
[phone chimes]
What if it's brown rice?
Nick took Bailey to the hospital.
I worked two nights ago and I'm the only person with my procedure card filled out.
I should be at home studying or sleeping...
Ask your co-chief resident for an exemption.
-[transporter] Coming through. - Nice try.
Oh, wow. Man.
[Helm] What happened?
Second floor deck collapsed,
mostly minor lacerations and musculoskeletal injuries,
but we're still waiting on a few rigs.
- They're all med... - Medical students.
They were having a white coat party. They just got theirs.
- I remember that party. I got super dr... -[clears throat]
Dramatic about reaching another milestone in my career.
Everybody grab a chart. It's gonna be a long night.
- [medical student] Come on. - [groans]
Hey, someone get him a CBC, type and screen, and hemoglobin.
- Stat. - It's okay. I'm okay.
- Mr. Oliver? - That's me. Eddie.
- It looks like he dislocated his left shoulder... -[Wilson clears throat]
So reduce it, get an MRI and page me with the results.
- So the X-ray showed it's not broken? - Exactly.
We'll do a local block and then I'll adduct your arm.
[Adams] Need any help?
- Uh, Kwan said he'll help me. - What?
Oh. Yeah, I... I got it.
Adams, rigs coming in. Grab a gown.
[groans]
- What are we doing? - Thank you.
[phone ringing]
[exhales heavily]
Hey. I was just gonna call you.
Where's Bailey?
Okay, so we're at the hospital.
He has early appendicitis.
They gave him antibiotics and morphine for the pain.
He's a little out of it.
- He needs an appy. Who's on call? - Ankrom.
She's gonna call you about consent.
Well, at least someone was thinking about that.
Yeah, look, I was gonna call, but...
I don't wanna talk about this now. I have to change my flight.
Tell Bailey I will be there as soon as I can.
Okay...
Meredith?
Mer?
[Hunt] What do we got?
[paramedic] Sophia Valdez, 26, impaled by a wood beam.
Oxygenating at 96% on room air, hemodynamically stable.
Bilateral neuro deficits in both lower extremities.
[sobbing] Please, you have to help me.
- Sophia, I'm Dr. Hunt. I know you're in a lot of pain. - This is killing me.
We're gonna do everything in our power to make sure that won't happen.
No, no. My coat... They took my white coat.
The one that lets everyone know I'm gonna be a doctor.
I'll... I'll try to find it for you.
I didn't even get to wear it at an actual hospital.
I can't feel my right leg,
and I'm only a first-year, but that's really bad, right?
Trauma three, page neuro. Let's go.
- Dr. Winston Ndugu? - Yes?
All right, let's make this quick.
I've got CCU rounds and a consult in a bit, all right?
Gilbert, sorry for the delay. I've had a lot of emergent cases today.
It's okay. I don't go anywhere anymore.
Strange places, loud noises, sudden movements,
they all make my heart go... [clicks tongue]
All right. We'll take care of that tonight, all right?
Dr. Millin?
Uh, Gilbert Quincy, 41, intermittent, rapid and irregular heart rate
accompanied by shortness of breath.
Initial diagnosis
is SVT with AVRT that is resistant to medication.
The patient is scheduled for a, um...
The patient is scheduled for a cardiac ablation.
[exhales heavily]
You know we can see you, right?
Angela's a professional cuddler.
When the anti-anxiety meds stopped working, I had to get creative.
[stammers]
You charge people to hug them?
Cuddling releases endorphins and oxytocin,
which lowers stress and anxiety.
That's fascinating.
Or a racket.
Okay, Gilbert, we gotta check on your labs, all right?
[sighs]
This is the worst possible time to consider having a baby.
Work never stops, my written exams are coming up and Luna's starting preschool...
Oh, my God, the diapers.
Do you know how many diapers we would need
if we had three kids who aren't potty trained?
Try not to panic. This could be nothing.
Six diapers a day per kid. That's, like, a thousand diapers a week.
- Not even close. - How could this happen? I'm ob-gyn.
Half my job is to help women not get pregnant.
- Oh, my God, here it is. - You're spiraling.
How are you not?
It won't be easy, but we'll figure it out.
Also, we live in a state where we have options.
If that's what you want, or not. I...
I just mean
we're in this together no matter what.
- [phone buzzes] - Oh.
[groans] Patient with abdominal pain.
You do realize this doesn't work if I take the test.
Sorry I'm late. Sophia, I'm Dr. Shepherd.
How are you feeling?
This isn't exactly how I pictured my first trauma.
How are my X-rays?
Okay, no visible injury around the lungs,
no free fluid in the abdomen or around the heart.
- She's a first-year med student. - Got it. Um...
Wiggle your toes for me.
[Sophia] Are they moving?
Okay. Can you feel it when I touch here?
Mm-mmm. [breathes shakily]
- We need a CT right now. - Okay.
[Sophia] I've wanted to be a surgeon ever since I can remember.
I watched Whipples on YouTube as a kid.
Have you ever done one?
Oh, my God. Is that...
Yeah, the paramedics were gonna toss it, but I got there just in time.
- [breathes heavily] It's so... - [Hunt] Sophia. Hey, hey, hey.
- Hey, hey, hey, hey. Deep breaths, okay? Stay still. -[sobbing]
Deep breaths. I'm gonna take you up to CT now.
Okay? Right now. We're going up. Let's go.
[Grey] I don't think you understand.
My son is in the hospital. I need a flight tonight.
Yes, I can hold.
Meredith?
What's going on?
Bailey needs an appendectomy.
He's with Nick in Boston.
- Can I help? - Can you fly a plane?
- No. But let me call Catherine. - No, I don't want to bother Catherine.
He's your son. Now, come on.
Excuse me.
Dr. Schmitt, I finished the arm lac in bed three. What's next?
We set up a fast track near bed seven for the simpler cases.
You should be able to move through that pretty quickly.
I was the fastest pre-rounder in medical school.
[Schmitt] Hmm.
All right.
Hi. I'm Dr. Yasuda...
[chuckling]
[sighs]
[Sophia] Do you have any idea how much I wanna be you?
[Adams] I haven't slept in two days. You might wanna rethink that.
Have you ever wanted a thing so much, it hurts?
Like... Like you can feel it in your body when you're so close to getting it?
Yeah, I, uh... I think I understand.
[breathing shakily] Then you know you have to fix me.
Please.
[Hunt] Adams, let's go.
When you see a deck collapse on TV,
are you thinking, "Gee, that's sad,"
or are you happy because of all the traumas? Be honest.
[inhales, clears throat]
Are you okay?
Yeah, I'm fine. [chuckles]
[monitors beeping]
Scans are up. Adams.
[Adams] It looks like the wood partially severed her spinal cord
at T4 and T5.
Brown-Séquard syndrome.
It's an expanding hematoma in her spinal cord
which means the blood supply is tenuous.
So what do you do?
We remove the foreign object,
we irrigate the hematoma,
we close her, and we hope for the best.
- Hope? - [Hunt] Mmm.
What... You just... You just hope that she's gonna be able to walk or stand?
Doing more could cause her entire spinal cord to stroke out.
Or she could die from complications.
[breathes heavily] This is her best option. Let's book an OR.
Mm-hmm.
[sighs]
[yawns]
Tired, Griffith?
- A little. - You should be.
I checked your hours. You're almost at your max. Go home.
I'm just waiting for Eddie Oliver's MRI results.
You know what exhausted interns do?
Make mistakes.
Which makes my life messy. You want my life to be messy, Griffith?
I will pass it off to Kwan and then go home. [chuckles]
[sighs] I have to give you my patient.
Uh, if his MRI is clear, he can be discharged. He's in bed four.
[Kwan] That bed's been empty for a while.
And you did nothing?
[scoffs] He wasn't my patient then.
Bailey will kill us
if we let a drunk medical student loose in the hospital.
- Find him. - Uh... You lost him.
Shut up and help me.
- [phone rings] - Hi.
[Grey] How is he?
He's good. Uh, they took him to pre-op.
And not before he lobbied the nurse for Popsicles after he wakes up.
- Well, I should be there by then. - Good.
He'll be happy.
Well, I could have been there sooner had I known.
Mer, we're gonna have this conversation now?
Well, you took my kid to the hospital.
Yeah. He said his stomach hurt on the way home from hockey practice.
I did a quick exam. He had rebound tenderness.
I called Ankrom. She said to bring him in. I mean...
You should have called me.
Yes, I could have.
I wanted to see what the doctor said before I worried you.
- I am a doctor. - Yes.
So am I.
I'm his mother. You call me.
Okay, copy that.
- The next time this happens... - No next time.
If any decisions need to be made, call me immediately.
Sounded like that went well.
[Yasuda] Track this for me.
This side.
- Okay, good. - Dead. Alive.
Dead. Alive.
- Dead. Alive. - Don't do that.
Dead.
I've been running the fast track area solo.
I heard. That's awesome.
Oh, is it?
'Cause so far, I've been peed on, spit on, and hit on.
I mean, the first two were accidents, but still.
Someone hit on you?
That's what you're concerned about?
Can you please swap me out?
- Let me see what I can do. - Okay.
- Can I have a sandwich? - No.
Back.
Wheelchair not a toy.
Hey. Gilbert Quincy still isn't prepped.
His heart rate kept going up while she was doing the echo.
I suggest we wait another 30 minutes before trying again.
Look, I've been on my feet since 5:00 this morning
and I've got eight hours ahead of me.
I'm not going to shift around my schedule
because my patient needs a human weighted blanket.
Uh, Angela, would you please go check on Gilbert?
We'll be in with you in a minute.
Thank you.
You're an intern. I give you a task, you do it. Understood?
Get the echo.
I will try again.
You know, actually, no.
You can do it intraoperatively while he's asleep.
Excuse me?
I know what I'm about to say is way out of line,
but it's late and I think you need to hear it.
You used to be the coolest attending.
Everybody wanted to be on your service.
But lately, you've kinda been a jerk.
Correct. This is way out of line. Yes.
Okay, I am desperate to learn from you,
but not if it means being disrespected
or standing by while you disrespect our patients.
Gilbert is in pain. He is scared.
And if paying someone to hug him helps him with that, who are we to judge?
I want the patient prepped within 20 minutes.
[Shepherd] Are you okay?
I've never been in an OR before.
Um... My... My dad said the OR had an invisible energy.
[chuckling] Like the Force in Star Wars.
[Shepherd] Hmm.
Now I get it.
What kind of surgeon is your dad?
Trauma. But he died two years ago.
[Shepherd] We are gonna start anesthesia.
Are you ready?
Can you make sure my coat is with my stuff?
I don't care if it's ruined. I still wanna keep it.
- [Hunt] Of course. - [Shepherd] Mm-hmm.
Okay.
I'm... I'm ready.
[chuckles] Eddie's MRI is clear.
[stammers] Maybe he went home. Did you try and give him a call?
I have been with you.
[sighs] Okay. Give me the number.
Thank you.
- You have reached the voicemail... - Voicemail.
I can't believe I lost a patient. Bailey is going to fire me.
Is he in a plaid shirt with a sling?
Is your missing patient wearing a plaid shirt and a sling on his arm?
- Yes. - Yeah, I saw him near the stairwell.
Ah. The one by the west elevator. Goes to the roof.
[both sigh]
Great. A windy outdoor version of what we've been doing all night.
[Kwan exhales heavily]
- Hey. - What?
Eddie.
Can you come down from there? We've got your MRI results.
Am I dying?
No, you're fine.
Let's go back in.
Yeah, we'll discharge you and you can go home.
Eddie? [breathes heavily]
What if I didn't go home?
You thought losing him was bad?
How about the headline:
"Drunk Med Student Falls off Hospital"?
He's completely sober according to his labs.
Or if I just...
let the wind decide?
[phone chimes]
[Webber] Oh.
[grunts] Anything new? [clears throat]
Still in surgery.
I wish I could see into that OR.
The last thing a surgeon needs is to have the patient's mom
looking over their shoulder.
Even more so if it's Meredith Grey.
Even the best hands make mistakes.
Bleeding. Perforations. It's the middle of the night.
They're tired. Mistakes happen.
They could, but most of the time they don't.
And most of the time, people who need craniotomies get head CTs.
I'm sorry. I'm fine. I just...
It's just when things like this happen, I know it's not Derek. I...
I understand. No apologies needed.
[Griffith] It's cold. Let's go in, get some coffee. Find your friends.
I'm fine here.
We can't leave you here.
Hey, Eddie. Did you...
Did you come up here to hurt yourself?
I don't know.
- Are you having thoughts of suicide? - I, uh...
I guess.
Sometimes.
I'm here if you wanna talk. We both are.
Maybe you could sit down. You've had a long night.
[Eddie] Seems darker up here.
The city.
Text Bailey.
Did you move here for med school or is Seattle home?
[medical student] You know, you're really pretty.
Yeah, thank you. Okay.
You like me?
Sure.
Don't touch that 'cause you're gonna open the sutures.
Okay?
Stop. Stop.
- Okay. You know what? - I'm not doing...
Your hand is contaminated and if you're not gonna listen,
- I have to do this. I'm sorry, I have to. - What...
This is just what has to happen right now, okay?
This is malpractice. Hey, she's malpracticing me.
Um, can... can I get another banana bag, please?
[medical student 2 chuckles]
No.
[scoffs]
Hey, baby.
Ah... I thought you weren't working tonight.
[chuckling] Well, I could say the same thing about you.
- [stammers] - Yeah, they needed a sub.
Wow. That med student party was a real rager, huh?
Yeah, I caught one of 'em trying to order pizza over at bed four.
- [chuckles] - Wait, Tuck's at home?
Uh... Did you remind him to lock the door and turn on the alarm?
- You didn't think I remembered. - [stammers, chuckles]
[phone chimes]
- Oh. Uh-oh. [gasps] - What? What happened?
Interns, uh, found a missing patient on the roof.
They're worried that he wants to jump off.
- Okay, well, tell 'em we're on the way. - Okay. Uh...
Do you remember how it felt to be that excited about surgery?
[Shepherd] Yeah, it was like a drug that,
-unlike the other drugs I was into, couldn't kill me. -[Hunt chuckles]
[Shepherd] Prepare for the specimen.
I don't remember the last time operating gave me that kind of rush.
Okay, removing the foreign object in three.
One. Two. Three.
- [Shepherd] Bovie. - [Hunt] Irrigation.
[Shepherd] Let's get this bleeding under control.
- Wash her out and get ready to close. -[Hunt] Okay.
- And let's hope for the best. - Okay.
[Hunt] These edges are cleaner than I thought they'd be.
No significant tissue loss. Bleeding's subsided.
You're gonna ask me to do a primary repair, aren't you?
That's not the standard of care.
I saw a lot of penetrating injuries like this in Iraq,
and I've seen primary repairs work on nerves and extremities.
It doesn't come close to a spinal cord.
But if you were going to do it?
I would need an ORBEYE.
I'd use 10-0 nylon.
Layer by layer I would need to expose the spinal cord...
I can't guarantee the outcome.
There's risky, and then there's this.
[Adams] She'd want you to do it.
Sorry. [stammering] But she'd want you to try.
It would kill her to know there was a chance and you didn't take it.
All right. This is gonna be long and tedious.
I need an ORBEYE.
I need everyone in lockstep. Are you in?
- [Hunt] I suggested it. - All right.
Okay.
[sighs] I can't look at it.
- Did you pee on this? - Just read it.
It's negative.
[exhales sharply]
What happened to we're in this together?
You... You were spiraling.
Short of traveling back and getting a vasectomy.
It was the only thing I could think of to make you feel better.
The idea of having a baby with me is so awful
you would rather have a vasectomy?
No. [stutters]
- A thousand diapers a week! - That was an exaggeration!
Hi.
I love being a dad.
And as much as I would love to do it all over again with you,
and only with you, I...
I'm tired. It's hard.
Just give me this.
It's not negative.
You... You're pregnant?
- It's not positive either. - Is there a third option?
One line is negative, two is positive.
- There's no lines. - It's a dud.
Oh.
[coughs]
[exclaims] Can... Can we slow down?
If we go any slower, we'll have to push your surgery to tomorrow.
[exclaims] Stop! Stop! I can't do this. I can't. I have to get off.
- I have to... - No, no, no.
You can do this. You can do this.
- Should we call Angela? - No! No.
She charges by the hour. I'm sorry, I'm really trying.
But my relaxation techniques aren't even working and I'm... I can't breathe.
And my fingers are tingling. I'm... I'm alone and I'm hot. Why is it so hot?
- Dr. Ndugu. What are you doing? - May I?
If his heart rate doesn't slow down, he can go into defib.
- [exhales sharply, exclaiming] - Just relax. Breathe.
You're okay. You're okay. You're okay. Breathe with me. Breathe with me.
- Breathe with me. - [breathing heavily]
Yep.
Okay, nice and slow.
Let's go.
Here you go.
I remember my white coat ceremony, my dad flew in.
But it was raining, so traffic was awful.
He walked in right as I was reciting the oath.
I barely passed my biochem test.
It's okay.
I studied.
I even went to see a tutor.
I busted my ass and I still couldn't even catch up.
Biochem is like learning another language.
So much reading.
So many tests.
You know, it's like I try to sleep, but I can't.
I think, uh...
Say it.
Sometimes just saying it helps.
[scoffs]
I think I'm broken.
I don't deserve this anymore.
Eddie!
[sighs]
[sighs]
[Bailey gasps]
Damn it, Griffith. I... I told her to go home.
- Well, it's a good thing she didn't listen. -[sighs]
Has he said anything about wanting to jump?
[stammers]
- No. - Good.
All right, well then, keep... Keep doing what you're doing.
He's standing on a ledge.
There's a difference between a suicide attempt and ideation.
All right. Right now, he's talking to her.
He's engaging with her and answering her questions.
But he's inches away from a seven-story drop.
And if we abruptly change the situation on him,
we might make it worse.
So calm down. Keep him talking.
[sighs]
- Hey, hey, hey. Hey, look at me. Look at me. Look at me. - Hmm?
- Five. Four. Three. Two. One. - [sighing]
Okay?
Any sign this becomes unstable...
We will intervene.
Hey.
Surgery went well. The appendix didn't rupture.
- He's still out? - You know him.
He could sleep through a monster truck rally without anesthesia.
You can go.
I... I don't need to.
You can go.
Okay.
His, uh... His vitals look good.
I'll let you two have some time,
but I'll be close in case you need anything.
Thank you for getting me here.
And for listening to me. And being there for me.
You know I would do more if I could.
I really am fine.
I mean, of course I miss him. I...
It's... It's just really only when the kids wake up in the middle of the night.
And I don't have anyone to talk to. And...
Anyway, you helped me more than you know.
I was glad to do it.
But, uh, you know I wasn't the only one you had to talk with.
- Mom? - Hi.
How do you feel?
Where's Nick?
[Shepherd] Pia mater has been approximated.
Cut please.
- Wait. There's bleeding. - [Hunt] Suction.
[Shepherd] Wait, no suction. No, it's too friable.
If we suction, we could lose spinal nerve tissue.
- We need to stop the bleeding. - We can irrigate
and then use Gelfoam soaked in dexamethasone.
[Hunt] Let's keep it quiet.
We know it's been a long night,
but we're on the homestretch, okay?
Bleeding has stopped. Gelfoam, please.
[Hunt] Do you need a dural patch?
No, I'm good.
I can't believe I'm saying this, but we can prep to close.
[Hunt chuckles]
- You did it. - We did.
[Shepherd] All right, wait to see that work before you start gloating up there.
[Hunt] Hmm.
[Shepherd] Okay. Irrigation.
How'd it go?
Good. Yeah. He's gonna wake up a new person.
I don't think we would have gotten him into the OR
if you hadn't jumped on the gurney when you did.
Yeah, well, gotta be honest, it's not my usual strategy.
Uh... Dr. Ndugu.
Um, I wanted to say that I am really sorry for what I said earlier.
Not only was it inappropriate and disrespectful, but...
It was right.
I haven't been bringing my best self to work lately.
[inhales heavily]
Things in my personal life are complicated, but it's no excuse.
You... You don't have to explain yourself to me.
No, I know. But I'm the coolest attending. [chuckles]
You did good work today.
[sighs]
[Griffith] You hungry?
Cafeteria has pretty good fries.
When did you feel like you were a doctor?
I don't know. Maybe a couple of weeks into residency.
Someone called me doctor tonight.
Patient in the elevator.
Guess he just saw the coat and assumed.
I didn't correct him.
That's okay.
It's a shame.
Not even sure what I am anymore.
I'm a guy just...
just going through the motions.
I take light-rail to school.
And every morning, I think...
what if I just fell onto the tracks?
Everyone else has it all figured out.
But I don't.
I don't know how to live with all of the, um...
Pressure and all the pain?
I didn't either.
A lot of people don't.
Doesn't matter how they make it look.
You're not alone.
And on most days,
I still don't feel like a doctor.
But I'm still here.
Let us get you some help.
[sighs]
[breathing shakily]
[Grey] Hi.
Do you have a minute?
Two days.
- Excuse me? - I've been with your kids for two days.
I got them to school. I got them to practice and rehearsal.
I made sure they ate, they slept.
When one of them felt sick,
out of an abundance of caution, I brought him here.
Now, yes, I guess I could have called on the way,
but I was busy making arrangements with your nanny
to take care of Zola and Ellis.
My kid was sick, and I wasn't here.
And I feel really guilty about that.
I'm all they have.
But you're not.
I mean, yes, you're their mom. Of course.
But they have so many people that love them.
Look, I know I'm not their father.
I know that, but I care about them a lot.
- And I want you to trust me with them. - I do trust you.
It doesn't feel like it.
I'm sorry.
I panicked.
I actually came here to say I'm sorry.
Because I know I panic.
And I was tired.
But I know that I said some things
that were probably pretty unnecessary to say.
- So... - A few things.
Okay. I've been doing this a long time alone,
so it may just take me a minute to adjust.
Hey, come here.
Look, I got a minute.
Okay?
